verse_commentaries.commentary: Remarkable triadic structure with three negations, three verbs of motion/position (walked/stood/sat), and three wicked categories (wicked/sinners/scoffers). The progression suggests intensifying entanglement. The beatitude formula אַשְׁרֵי opens the entire Psalter. The man is defined first by what he does NOT do—righteousness begins in negative space.

lexical_insights.notes: Beatitude formula - wisdom genre marker; plural construct of happiness/blessedness
First verb in triadic progression - transient movement, beginning of involvement
Second verb - standing, pausing; intermediate stage of entanglement
Third verb - sitting, dwelling; settled residence, final stage of progression
Scoffers/insolent ones - most intense category in triadic wicked list; technical wisdom term
Counsel/advice - wisdom terminology; what sphere is avoided

figurative_analysis: Walking/standing/sitting as spatial metaphors for social-ethical involvement
Three wicked categories may represent intensification or distinct types
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes the 'two ways' framework foundational to thesis; righteousness defined first negatively (avoidance) before positive definition

verse_commentaries.commentary: Sharp pivot with כִּי אִם (but rather) from negative to positive definition. Torah appears twice with possessive suffix, showing intimate relationship. The merismus יוֹמָם וָלָיְלָה (day and night) signals totality. The verb יֶהְגֶּה is ambiguous—does it mean murmur/mutter (vocalized) or meditate (internal)?

lexical_insights.notes: Adversative particle pair - 'but rather'; creates strong contrast with verse 1
Torah of YHWH - central term; teaching/instruction becomes object of delight
His delight/pleasure - affective dimension of Torah engagement
Meditates/murmurs/mutters - crucial ambiguous verb; vocal or mental practice?
Day and night - merismus indicating totality/continuity; echoes Joshua 1:8

figurative_analysis: Torah as object of delight (חֵפֶץ) - normally desire for things/people, here for text
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Core thesis element: Torah meditation as mark of righteousness and lens for Psalter; shift from cultic to text-centered piety

verse_commentaries.commentary: Extended emblematic simile with rich agricultural imagery. The verb שָׁתוּל (planted) is passive—divine agency implied? The tree has four positive attributes: yields fruit, in season, foliage unfading, everything prospers. The phrase וְכֹל אֲשֶׁר־יַעֲשֶׂה יַצְלִיחַ broadens beyond tree metaphor to comprehensive success.

lexical_insights.notes: Planted (passive participle) - suggests divine action, not self-made; differs from נָטַע
Streams/channels of water - sustained irrigation, not occasional rain; deliberate water supply
In its season - appropriate timing, reliability, not random productivity
Wither/fade - negated; sustained vitality even when not fruiting
Prosper/succeed/thrive - comprehensive flourishing; echoes Joseph narrative

figurative_analysis: Tree as metaphor for righteous person - organic, rooted, fruitful existence
Water streams suggest continuous Torah supply from v.2
Foliage that doesn't fade - vitality even in non-productive seasons
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Central positive image supporting thesis: Torah meditation produces organic, fruitful, substantial being; contrasts with chaff in v.4

verse_commentaries.commentary: Abrupt, stark contrast introduced by לֹא־כֵן (not so). Dramatically shorter than vv.1-3—structural asymmetry performs the message (wicked lack substance even poetically). Single terse image: chaff blown by wind. The כִּי אִם creates parallel to v.2 but inverts meaning.

lexical_insights.notes: Not so - sharp negation; emphatic reversal of tree imagery
Like chaff - agricultural waste product from threshing; weightless, worthless, disposable
Drives it away/scatters - violent dispersal; chaff has no resistance to wind
Wind/spirit - natural force or divine judgment? Ambiguous agent

figurative_analysis: Chaff as anti-tree: no roots, no weight, no permanence, no fruit
Wind as agent of dispersal - possibly divine judgment
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Provides stark antithesis supporting thesis binary; structural asymmetry demonstrates ontological difference between rooted vs. rootless existence

verse_commentaries.commentary: Draws legal/eschatological consequences from v.4 with עַל־כֵּן (therefore). Two parallel exclusions: wicked won't 'stand' in judgment, sinners won't be in righteous assembly. The verb יָקֻמוּ is ambiguous—judicial standing or resurrection? The עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים is mysterious—liturgical, eschatological, or metaphorical community?

lexical_insights.notes: Therefore - causal connection drawing consequence from chaff imagery
Stand/arise - judicial language? Eschatological? Echoes עָמָד from v.1 (stood)
In the judgment - definite article suggests specific judgment; when/what is this?
Assembly/congregation of righteous - cultic? Eschatological? Social?

figurative_analysis: Assembly as spatial metaphor for inclusion/belonging
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Extends thesis binary into eschatological/communal dimension; wicked excluded from divine recognition (v.6 preview)

verse_commentaries.commentary: Theological pivot from human ethics to divine epistemology. The כִּי (for/because) grounds the entire preceding binary. YHWH 'knows' (יוֹדֵעַ) the righteous way—covenantal, relational knowing, not mere cognition. The wicked way 'perishes' (תֹּאבֵד)—not just fails morally but dissolves ontologically. Inclusio with דֶּרֶךְ from v.1 frames entire psalm. Striking asymmetry: active divine knowing vs. intransitive perishing.

lexical_insights.notes: Knows - covenant epistemology; intimate recognition, not mere awareness (cf. Amos 3:2)
Way of righteous - inclusio with v.1; life as path/orientation
Perishes/is destroyed - intransitive; ontological dissolution, not just moral failure
Way of wicked - contrasts with way of righteous; perishes rather than is known

figurative_analysis: Way as metaphor for life-path/orientation (not single choice but trajectory)
Perishing as ontological metaphor (dissolution into non-being)
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Crucial for thesis: grounds entire binary in divine knowledge/recognition; righteous way exists because God knows it; wicked way lacks divine recognition and thus dissolves—ontological not just moral claim

thematic_threads: Structural asymmetry performs theological message: righteous get elaborate description (3 verses, rich imagery), wicked get sparse treatment (shorter, single image)—poetic form enacts ontological difference
Inclusio with דֶּרֶךְ (way) frames entire psalm: v.1 'way of sinners', v.6 'way of righteous/wicked'—life as path/orientation, not discrete choices
Progressive definition strategy: righteous defined first negatively (v.1 avoidance), then positively (v.2 Torah engagement), then consequentially (v.3 flourishing)
Triadic patterns: three negations, three verbs, three wicked types (v.1); three elements in tree description building to comprehensive success (v.3)
Two pivots with כִּי אִם (but rather): v.2 (from negative to positive definition) and v.4 (from righteous to wicked contrast)—structural parallelism with inverted meaning
Passive constructions suggesting divine agency: שָׁתוּל (planted) in v.3, תֹּאבֵד (perishes) in v.6—neither righteousness nor wickedness are fully self-made
Sound patterns create cohesion: alliteration in v.1 (/ʔaʃ-reː hɔ-ʔiːʃ ʔa-ʃɛr/), assonance in v.3, repeated Torah sounds in v.2
Shift from ethics (vv.1-5) to ontology/epistemology (v.6)—final verse regrounds the binary in divine knowledge, not human morality
interesting_questions: What is the precise semantic difference between הָלַךְ (walked), עָמָד (stood), and יָשָׁב (sat) in v.1—are these stages of progressive entanglement, spatial metaphors, or synonymous variations for poetic effect?
Does יֶהְגֶּה (meditate/murmur) in v.2 indicate vocalized, embodied practice (murmuring, recitation aloud) or internal contemplation, and how does this affect understanding of Torah engagement?
Why is the tree שָׁתוּל (planted, passive) in v.3 rather than using an active verb—does this suggest divine agency positioning the righteous rather than self-made righteousness?

What is the function and background of חַף (chaff) imagery in v.4—how does this connect to threshing floor scenes as judgment contexts elsewhere in Scripture, and what does it suggest about wicked ontology?
What does יָקֻמוּ (stand/arise) mean in v.5—is this purely judicial language (standing in court), eschatological/resurrection imagery, or deliberately ambiguous?
What is the 'assembly of the righteous' (עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים) in v.5—a liturgical/cultic gathering, eschatological community, social reality, or metaphor for the blessed state?

What does יוֹדֵעַ (knows) connote in v.6—epistemological awareness, relational/covenantal acknowledgment (cf. Amos 3:2), or ontologically constitutive knowing (God's knowledge creates/sustains reality)?

How do the three wicked categories in v.1—רְשָׁעִים (wicked), חַטָּאִים (sinners), לֵצִים (scoffers)—relate: are they synonymous, progressive stages of wickedness, or distinct types, and what specifically does לֵצִים add?
Why does the wicked way 'perish' (תֹּאבֵד) in v.6 with no explicit agent—is this divine action, inherent consequence of lacking divine recognition, or self-destruction?
How does Psalm 1 function redactionally as introduction to the Psalter, especially in relation to Psalm 2 (same הָגָה verb used contrastively, both mention blessing, possible original unity)?
What is the significance of the structural asymmetry—elaborate righteous description vs. sparse wicked description—is this deliberate rhetorical choice to perform ontological difference?
Why 'streams' (plural, פַּלְגֵי־מָיִם) in v.3 rather than a single water source—does this suggest continuous, abundant, deliberate irrigation system as metaphor for Torah supply?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on יֶהְגֶּה (murmur/meditate), יוֹדֵעַ (knows), יָקֻמוּ (stand/arise), לֵצִים (scoffers), שָׁתוּל (planted), עֲדַת (assembly)
CONCORDANCE: Track דֶּרֶךְ (way) inclusio pattern; אַשְׁרֵי beatitudes across Psalter; הָגָה verb usage (Ps 2:1 contrasting meditation); tree/plant imagery; chaff imagery in judgment contexts
FIGURATIVE: Tree/water imagery (v.3), chaff/wind imagery (v.4), way/path metaphors (vv.1,6), knowing as relational metaphor (v.6)
COMMENTARY: V.2 meditation practice (vocal vs. internal), v.5 'the judgment' (eschatological?), v.6 divine knowing (epistemology/ontology), redactional function as Psalter introduction
